§ 34.01  HOLIDAYS.
   Holidays shall be observed as follows:
   (A)   Ten paid holidays and two personal leave days are recognized by the
city throughout the year; they are:
      (1)   New Year's Day.
      (2)   Martin Luther King Day.
      (3)   Memorial Day (last Monday in May).
      (4)   Independence Day (July 4).
      (5)   Labor Day.
      (6)   Columbus Day (second Monday in October).
      (7)   Thanksgiving Day.
      (8)   The day following Thanksgiving.
      (9)   Christmas Eve.
      (10)   Christmas Day.
      (11)   Personal leave day.
      (12)   Personal leave day.
   (B)   Any special holidays declared by the Congress or the President of the
United States or the General Assembly or Governor of the state shall be
recognized as official holidays.
   (C)   If one of the above holidays should fall on a Sunday, it will be
observed on the following Monday, or, if the holiday should fall on Saturday,
it will be observed on the preceding Friday.  All holidays shall be observed as
stipulated in national or state holiday bill.
   (D)   Holidays which occur during vacation leave shall not be charged
against vacation.
   (E)   Whenever an employee is absent from work and not in paid status on the
work day before a holiday or the work day after a holiday, he shall not be paid
for the holiday.
   (F)   Employees in the Police Department or other operational services who
are required by virtue of work schedule to work during an approved holiday
shall receive one day's compensatory time off to be scheduled at the discretion
of the department head.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 3-1981, passed 1-1981; Am. Ord. 2-1985,
passed 1-7-85; Am. Ord. 2-1986, passed 1-20-86)
§ 34.02  VACATIONS.
   (A)   Each regular and full-time employee is eligible for vacation with pay
in accordance with his length of service based upon a calendar year as follows.
      (1)   Thereafter, any employee with continuous service of at least one
year, but less than five years, shall receive vacation with pay of two basic
work weeks.
      (2)   Beginning with the year in which an employee will reach his fifth
anniversary of continuous service, through the year the employee will reach his
twelfth anniversary of continuous service, he shall receive vacation with pay
of three basic work weeks.
      (3)   Beginning with the year in which the employee reaches his
thirteenth year of continuous service through the year the employee will reach
his nineteenth anniversary of continuous service, that employee shall receive
vacation with pay of four basic work weeks.
      (4)   Beginning with the year in which an employee will reach his
twentieth year of continuous service and thereafter that employee shall receive
vacation with pay of five basic work weeks.
      (5)   Vacation time will not be permitted to accrue to an amount beyond
that accrued annually except under such unusual work load circumstances when it
has been impossible for the employee to take his vacation and then only with
the written permission of the department head and the City Manager.  In no
event shall vacation leave be permitted to accrue beyond that accumulated in a
two-year period, and in no event shall it exceed a maximum of five calendar
weeks.  The time which an employee shall take his vacation shall be determined
by the department head with due regard for the needs of the service.  Vacation
leave shall be taken by employees in not less than 1/2-day units. Regular full-
time employees who are separated from the service may be compensated for
vacation accrued up to the date of separation.
      (6)   For an employee leaving the service, the City Manager shall deduct
from any ordinary vacation pay sums which the employee may owe to the city, and
the employee shall be entitled to receive only the amount of the vacation pay
less the amount of the deduction.
      (7)   Vacation pay shall be based on normal pay received for a 40-hour
work week.
      (8)   An employee who resigns without giving at least ten calendar days
prior written notice shall forfeit any unused vacation leave to his credit, or
pay in lieu thereof, on the date of resignation.
      (9)   In the event an employee dies while in paid status in the city
service, any unused vacation leave to his credit shall be paid in a lump sum to
the surviving spouse, or to the estate of the deceased.
      (10)   When a city-observed holiday falls within the employee's scheduled
vacation period, the employee shall be granted an additional day off with pay.
      (11)   Any employee of the city who has previously worked for the state
or any political subdivision of the state shall be allowed to transfer
seniority work time from his previous employer for the purposes of determining
eligible vacation time with the city.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 7-1982, passed 3-1-82; Am. Ord. 12-1982,
passed 5-17-82; Am. Ord. 2-1985, passed 1-7-85)
   (B)   Each permanent part-time employee who is regularly scheduled for not
less than 1,040 hours per year is eligible for 40 hours of vacation with pay
each year, after completion of one calendar year's service with the following
conditions:
      (1)   Vacation time will not be permitted to accrue to an amount beyond
that accrued annually, except under such unusual work circumstances when it has
been impossible for the permanent part-time employee to take his vacation, and
then only with the written permission of the department head and the City
Manager.  In no event shall vacation leave be permitted to accrue beyond that
accumulated in a two-year period.  The time which a permanent part-time
employee shall take his vacation shall be determined by the department head
with due regard for the needs of the city.  Permanent part-time employees who
are separated from the service may be compensated for vacation accrued up to
the date of separation.
      (2)   For a permanent part-time employee leaving the service, the City
Manager shall deduct from the ordinary vacation pay sums which the permanent
part-time employee may owe the city, and the permanent part-time employee shall
be entitled to receive only the amount of vacation pay less the amount of
deduction.
      (3)   A permanent part-time employee who resigns without giving at least
ten calendar days prior written notice shall forfeit any unused vacation leave
to his credit, or pay in lieu thereof, on the date of separation.
      (4)   In the event a permanent part-time employee dies while in paid
status of the city service, any unused vacation leave to his credit shall be
paid in a lump sum to the surviving spouse, or to the estate of the deceased.
(Ord. 2-1984, passed 1-3-84)
§ 34.03  HEALTH, DENTAL AND LIFE INSURANCE.
   It is the intention of City Council to provide health insurance and term
insurance for all regular and full-time employees and health insurance for
regular long-term part-time employees as follows:
   (A)   The city may enter into contractual agreements for the purpose of
providing health insurance for all regular and full-time employees, and pay a
negotiated portion of the premiums for both the employee and family coverage. 
The city may also offer regular long-term part-time employees health and dental
insurance at the group rate to be paid by the regular long-term part-time
employee.
   (B)   The city may draw specifications for term life insurance, as is now in
effect, in order to provide term life insurance and other benefits for all
regular and full-time employees.  Unless otherwise covered by a contractual
agreement, the amount of life insurance offered to all regular full-time
employees will be equal to $75,000 or to the employee’s annual base salary,
whichever is greater, effective January 1, 2018.
   (C)   For the purpose of this section, REGULAR AND FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES is
defined as including all employees who perform prescribed duties on an
established schedule of 40 hours or more per week.  Employees working 20 hours
or more per calendar week schedule are to be considered regular long-term part-
time employees.  Employees working seasonal, limited term, temporary, or an
average of less than 20 hours per calendar week are to be considered part-time
employees and shall be excluded from such insurance programs.
   (D)   Employees working 40 hours or more per week, but in a position which
is intended to exist and continue for only a portion of a calendar year (known
as seasonal employees) shall not be considered regular or full-time employees
or regular long-term part-time employees and shall be excluded from such
insurance programs.
   (E)   Insurance co-payment.
      (1)   Effective January 1, 2009, all employees participating in the
health insurance plan shall, through payroll deduction, contribute 15% of the
cost of the monthly health insurance premium.
      (2)   No deduction shall be made if an employee submits a written
statement 30 days in advance indicating that they do not want to be enrolled in
any city-provided medical insurance plan.
   (F)   Flexible medical benefit.  In order to assist full-time employees who
participate in the health or dental insurance programs for uncovered costs (co-
pays, deductibles, etc.), employees will be eligible for reimbursement of $200
for family coverage or $100 for single coverage annually.  Employees who are
not employed the full year will have this benefit prorated by the number of
months worked during the year (annual benefit amount divided by 12 months times
the number of months worked during the year).
   (G)   Retired government employee part-time stipend. Effective August 1,
2018 and at the City Manager’s discretion, retired government employees who are
hired by the city in a part-time or seasonal capacity, may be eligible to
receive a medical stipend equal to their forfeited pension health reimbursement
allowance or similar forfeitures due to their part-time employment status. This
stipend shall not exceed $500 per month.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-7l; Am. Ord. 11-1987, passed 1-20-87; Am. Ord. 10-
1988, passed 3-21-88; Am. Ord. 2-1989, passed 1-16-89; Am. Ord. 13-1990, passed
5-21-90; Am. Ord. 05-2003, passed 5-5-03; Am. Ord. 23-2018, passed 9-17-18)
§ 34.04  SICK LEAVE.
   Sick leave with pay shall be granted to all full-time employees at the rate
of 1-1/4 work days for each full month of active service. An employee on
probationary status may utilize sick leave at the discretion of the department
head who may require a certificate from a licensed physician.
   (A)   Sick leave shall not be considered as a privilege which an employee
may use at his discretion, but shall be allowed only in case of necessary and
actual sickness or disability of the employee, or because of illness in his
immediate family which necessitates his absence from employment.
   (B)   To receive compensation while absent on sick leave, the employee shall
notify his immediate superior prior to the time set for beginning his daily
duties.  The department head may require an employee to furnish a satisfactory
written affidavit to justify the use of sick leave.  If medical attention is
required, or if an employee is absent for more than four consecutive working
days, a certificate stating the nature of the illness from a licensed physician
may be required to justify the use of sick leave with pay.
   (C)   Unused sick leave may be accumulated to a total of not more than 225
working days for regular full-time employees who are normally entitled to
benefits and who are not specifically covered by a labor agreement.  The
employee shall not be compensated for unused sick leave except as provided in
the options below:
      (1)   Upon retirement from city service and approval of retirement
benefits in a State of Ohio public employee retirement system, an employee may
be compensated for accumulated sick leave days at the rate of one day's pay for
each two days accumulated with a maximum payment equal to not more than 112.5
days of pay.
      (2)   Upon submitting a resignation for retirement purposes and
acceptance of such resignation by the City Manager, an employee who is eligible
to receive retirement benefits in a state of Ohio public employee retirement
system may take terminal leave at the rate of one day for each two days of
accumulated sick leave (112.5 days maximum leave) immediately preceding the
effective date of resignation. An employee shall not earn sick leave while on
terminal leave.
      (3)   An employee may select only one of the above stated options or the
One-Time Good Attendance Bonus in §
34.041, but may not combine the above stated options.  Upon payment under
option (1) or the exhaustion of terminal leave under option (2), an employee's
sick leave balance will be reduced to zero.
   (D)   An employee who transfers from another public agency to the city shall
be credited with the unused balance of his accumulated sick leave up to the
maximum permitted by the city, upon receipt by the City Manager of a written
statement signed by the employee's previous appointing authority or personnel
officer attesting to the amount of unused accumulated sick leave claimed and
certifying that the individual has not been in any way compensated for the
unused sick leave claimed. This section shall apply to all future employees
only upon their permanent appointment to a position in the city government.  In
the event, however, that the employee has been compensated for unused sick
leave by the previous employer, no such credit balance shall be permitted.
   (E)   Pregnancy is not an illness, however an employee who has accumulated
sick leave may utilize their sick leave during or after their pregnancy if they
are directed by their doctor to quit work, and may continue the use of their
sick leave until they are given permission by their doctor to return to work.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 4-1983, passed 1-17-83; Am. Ord. 11-
1983, passed 4-4-83; Am. Ord. 2-1984, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 2-1989, passed 1-
16-89; Am. Ord. 13-1990, passed 5-21-90; Am. Ord. 07-1997, passed 3-3-97; Am.
Ord. 15-1997, passed 5-19-97)
§ 34.041  ONE-TIME GOOD ATTENDANCE BONUS.
   Upon approval and certification of the City Manager, a city employee who has
obtained 20 years of continuous service with the city, and who has accumulated
a sick leave balance of not less than 150 days, said employee may receive a
one-time good attendance bonus, calculated by multiplying the employee's
current per diem rate (regular scheduled hours per day X hourly rate) by one-
half of the number of accumulated sick leave days accrued by the employee and
credited to the employee's sick leave balance. Regularly scheduled hours per
day shall not exceed eight unless assigned to a regular schedule, approved by
the City Manager, in excess of eight hours per day.
(Ord. 15-1997, passed 5-19-97)
§ 34.042  OUTSTANDING ATTENDANCE PROGRAM.
   For each three hours in excess of 1,800 hours of continued outstanding
attendance, an employee will earn one hour, up to a maximum of five days, of
earned time (a rate of approximately 3.333 hours per month).  The outstanding
attendance earnings shall not be accumulated from year to year.  At the end of
the calendar year, any unused balance shall be paid out directly to the
employee at the rate of one hour of pay for each hour earned, and there shall
be no carry over of said time from year to year.
(Ord. 04-1999, passed 5-3-99; Am. Ord. 16-2001, passed 10-1-01)
§ 34.05  INJURY LEAVE WITH PAY.
   Leave with pay shall be granted to persons injured while on the job in
accordance with the following.
   (A)   All city employees shall be allowed injury leave with pay not to
exceed six calendar months for each service connected injury provided such
injury is reported to the employee's immediate supervisor subject to the
provisions of this section.
   (B)   Compensation during the injury leave shall be his regular pay less any
pay from disability or workman's compensation but he will be fully compensated
during the waiting period.
   (C)   Injury leave with pay shall be granted to any employee only for
injuries or other disabilities determined by the City Physician as caused or
induced by the actual performance of the duties of his or her position.
   (D)   A report of the cause of all injuries signed by the immediate
supervisor, the department head, and the City Physician shall be filed within
two work days of the date of the injury on forms designated and furnished by
the Civil Service Commission.  The City Physician shall be required to submit a
report to the Civil Service Commission, following each accident, indicating
what steps have been taken to remove or correct the cause of the disability,
and such report shall be prepared and submitted within ten working days of the
date on which the report of the accident was received by him.
   (E)   No employee shall be granted injury leave with pay unless the City
Manager has in his possession written authorization signed by the City
Physician.  This authorization shall indicate the approximate length of the
leave, and no injured employee on leave shall be returned to work without the
written approval of the City Physician. If, in the judgment of the City
Physician, the injury is such that the employee is capable of performing his
regular duties or light duties during the period of convalescence, he shall so
notify the City Manager in writing and deny injury leave with pay.  Whenever an
employee is required to stop working because of an injury or other service
connected disability, he shall be paid for the remaining hours of that day, or
shift, at his regular rate and such time shall not be charged to leave of any
kind.
   (F)   Any injured employee may appeal the decision of the City Physician to
the Civil Service Commission within five calendar days of notification that
injury leave has been denied.
   (G)   Pending a decision by the City Physician, an injured employee may be
carried on personal sick leave with pay which shall be restored to his credit
upon certification by the City Physician that injury leave has been approved.
   (H)   Time off for the purpose of medical examinations or treatments
resulting from injury on the job shall be charged to injury leave.
   (I)   The provisions of this section shall be administered by the City
Manager who shall make necessary rules, devise forms, keep records, investigate
cases, and make decisions on allowance of pay for time off duty as provided by
this section, subject to the approval of the Civil Service Commission.
   (J)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to intentional self-
inflicted injury.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71)
§ 34.06  SPECIAL LEAVE WITH PAY.
   Leave with pay may be granted to employees for the following:
   (A)   Military leave shall be granted consistent with current state laws.
   (B)   Jury duty leave.
      (1)   A city employee while serving on a jury will be paid his regular
salary for the period of time so served less whatever amount the employee may
receive as compensation for his services as a juror.  Time so served shall be
deemed active service with this city for all purposes.
      (2)   A city employee, subpoenaed in a court of record or a Mayor's court
or other lawful proceedings will be paid at 1-1/2  times his compensatory time
rate, unless on duty or during regular work hours, and on proper dismissal from
that subpoena may collect and retain any fees lawfully paid to him by the
authority.
   (C)   Examination leave.  Time off with pay shall be allowed city employees
participating in city civil service tests, or taking a required examination
pertinent to their city employment before a state or federal licensing board.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 7-1982, passed 3-1-82)
§ 34.07  OTHER LEAVES OF ABSENCE WITH PAY.
   An employee may be granted up to five days leave of absence with pay upon
the recommendation of the department head in case of a death in the employee's
family.  EMPLOYEE'S FAMILY may include father, mother, sister, brother, wife,
husband, or children, step-children, in-laws, and other relatives at the
discretion of the department head, but would normally include only members of
the immediate family.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71)
§ 34.08  UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   It is the intent to provide uniforms or special clothing for all personnel
required to wear such clothing in accordance with the following provisions.
   (A)   Employees required by the department head to wear prescribed uniforms
in the performance of their duties as city employees shall be furnished such
uniforms and replacements as needed in accordance with the rules established by
the City Manager.
   (B)   The City Manager may enter into contractual agreements or negotiate as
part of an employment benefit package for providing personnel with uniforms and
cleaning service or an allowance as deemed appropriate.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 10-2000, passed 9-18-00)
§ 34.09  TUITION REFUND PROGRAM.
   As a further aid to improve employee proficiency, the city may grant a
tuition refund to employees each year for completing courses or programs,
provided that the following requirements are met.
   (A)   An employee must have had at least two years of satisfactory service
with the city and must have, in advance, the written approval of his department
head and the City Manager.
   (B)   The course of instruction is related to the employee's current
position.
   (C)   (1)   The city's share shall be limited to $450 for employees with two
to five years of service; and $900 for employees with five or more years of
service.  The city's limit shall be adjusted in accordance with the employee's
final grade and in accordance with the schedule of years of service as follows:
      Grade A         Reimbursement Maximum
      "B" or better         Full reimbursement maximum
      "C" or better   *      Half of reimbursement maximum
      Grades below "C",      No tuition refund
      Incomplete, or failure
      (2)   The City Manager may authorize tuition reimbursement to be applied
towards the employee's lab fees and/or book purchases that are required as part
of the course when deemed in the best interest of the city.
   * In the alternative, a "pass" grade on a pass/fail schedule shall be
eligible for half of the reimbursement maximum.
   (D)   The City Manager shall be responsible for determining the propriety of
the course.
   (E)   The Director of Finance shall be responsible for keeping complete
records for the financial administration of this program.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 7-1982, passed 3-1-82; Am. Ord. 13-1990,
passed 5-21-90; Am. Ord. 04-1992, passed 1-21-92)
§ 34.091  COLLEGE TUITION SAVINGS PLAN.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to develop and administer
for employees a college tuition savings plan commonly referred to as a 529
college tuition savings plan.  Said college tuition savings plan may provide a
flat $10 per month employer contribution per participating employee.
(Ord. 11-2002, passed 7-1-02; Am. Ord. 18-2003, passed 12-15-03)
§ 34.10  TRAVEL ALLOWANCE.
   Any employee of the city may attend at the expense of the city, any
conference, meeting or convention relating to municipal affairs, if authorized
by the City Manager and if the Director of Finance certifies that funds are
appropriate and available for such purposes. All requests for such allowances
shall be made in writing to the City Manager, showing the necessity for such
attendance and an estimate of the costs to the city at a reasonable period of
time in advance.  Current mileage allowances will be permitted for use of
privately owned vehicles.  The City Manager shall establish administrative
guidelines to permit the reimbursement of employees for properly documented
meal expenses, including gratuities, that are incurred during the course of
conducting city business.
(Ord. 17-1971, passed 4-5-71; Am. Ord. 22-2001, passed 12-17-01)
§ 34.11  TRAVEL REIMBURSEMENT EXPENSE AND AUTOMOBILE ALLOWANCE OF EMPLOYEES AND
OFFICIALS.
   (A)   Reimbursed travel expense.  The City Manager is authorized to
establish a procedure for the reimbursement of approved travel expense,
incurred by city employees and city officials, while in the performance of
their official duties on behalf of the city.
   (B)   Rate of compensation.  The rate of reimbursement shall be computed at
the rate approved by the Internal Revenue Service.
   (C)   Vouchers.  Upon presentation of vouchers approved by the City Manager,
the Director of Finance (Treasurer) is authorized to pay the amounts and charge
the proper accounts.
   (D)   City Manager.
      (1)   In lieu of the rate approved by the Internal Revenue Service
authorized to employees and officials, the City Manager shall receive a yearly
automobile allowance of $4440 payable in equal monthly installments, for all
travel within Hamilton, Clermont, and Butler Counties.
      (2)   For travel outside Hamilton, Clermont and Butler Counties, he shall
receive reimbursement at the rate approved by the Internal Revenue Service.
(Ord. 34-1973, passed 5-21-73; Am. Ord. 4-1980, passed 2-18-80; Am. Ord. 7-
1982, passed 3-1-82; Am. Ord. 2-1985, passed 1-7-85; Am. Ord. 13-1990, passed
5-21-90; Am. Ord. 06-1994, passed 3-7-94; Am. Ord. 02-1997, passed 2-3-97; Am.
Ord. 01-1999, passed 1-19-99)
§ 34.12  LONGEVITY PAY PROGRAM.
   (A)   It is the expressed intent of the City Council to establish, effective
July 1, 1982, a longevity pay program through the use of an individual
retirement account program.  The contribution by the city to the IRA program
would be as follows:
      (1)   Less than ten years service, 1%.
      (2)   Ten years to 24 years service, 2%.
      (3)   25 or more years service, 3%.
   (B)   It is understood by the Council that employees will be offered the
option of the IRA program or cash in lieu of the IRA program, but that if a
cash offering is made, it will be with deductions of taxes and pension
contributions.
   (C)   Payment of longevity pay will be made in one check on February 1,
either in cash or deposited in an IRA account.  Employees electing to receive
cash shall receive the appropriate amount subject to regular withholding for
taxes and retirement.  All longevity pay, whether paid to an IRA account or in
cash, will be subject to withholding of pension contributions and city taxes.
(Res. 16-1982, passed 3-1-82; Am. Ord. 2-1984, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 13-1984,
passed 4-16-84)
§ 34.13  RETIREMENT.
   Any employee is eligible, and may file an application with the City Manager,
for retirement upon meeting those criteria for retirement as established within
the appropriate public retirement system for the employee's classification.
(Ord. 11-1983, passed 4-4-83; Am. Ord. 16-1983, passed 4-4-83)
§ 34.14  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   Unless otherwise covered by contract or employment agreement with the city,
this chapter shall apply.

GENERAL POLICE DEPARTMENT PROVISIONS
§ 35.01  POLICE DEPARTMENT STRUCTURE.
   The Police Department of the city shall be composed of such personnel as may
be recommended by the City Manager and approved by resolution of City Council.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-20-75)
§ 35.02  PUBLIC AUCTION OF PROPERTY IN POLICE CUSTODY.
   The Chief of Police shall dispose of abandoned, stolen, or forfeited
property, unclaimed for a period of 90 days, by sale at a public auction.
   (A)   Due notice of the public auction will be given by advertisement,
published once a week for three successive weeks in a newspaper of general
circulation in the community.
   (B)   The proceeds from the property disposed of by sale at public auction
shall be paid to the Director of Finance of the city and credited to the city's
General Fund.
(Ord. 38-1983, passed 7-18-83)
§ 35.03  LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   There is hereby established a Law Enforcement Trust Fund for receipts and
proceeds from the sale of contraband as provided in R.C. § 2933.43.  This Fund
shall be allocated only to the Forest Park Division of Police and shall be
expended only to pay the cost of protracted or complex investigations or
prosecutions, to provide reasonable technical training or expertise, to provide
matching funds to obtain federal grants to aid law enforcement, or for such
other law enforcement purposes as determined by this Council to be appropriate
in accord with Ohio Law.  The City Finance Director is hereby directed to
establish and maintain the Law Enforcement Trust Fund provided for herein.
(Ord. 6-1988, passed 2-15-88)
RESERVE POLICE UNIT
§ 35.05  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is created within the City Police Department, a reserve police unit,
the members of which shall be appointed by the City Manager.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.06  LENGTH OF SERVICE.
   Reserve police officers shall serve so long as the City Manager may direct,
or until a resignation submitted by such members shall be accepted by the City
Manager.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.07  REQUIREMENTS.
   The members of the reserve police unit shall meet the residency requirements
of regular police officers and may not be under the age of 21 years at the time
of their appointment; and such other requirements as provided by the rules and
regulations provided for in §
35.09.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.08  CHIEF OF POLICE TO BE COMMANDING OFFICER.
   The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the reserve police
unit and shall have control of the assignment, training, stationing, and the
direction of work of such unit.  The reserve police unit will have all police
powers, but shall perform only such police duties as assigned by the Chief of
Police and shall act only when in the prescribed uniform or portion of
uniform.  The Chief of Police shall prescribe the time and place such uniform
or portion thereof shall be worn.  Such reserve members shall obey the chain of
command of the Police Department and shall take orders from all regularly
appointed members thereof.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.09  CITY MANAGER SHALL PRESCRIBE RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The City Manager shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the
organization, administration, conduct, and control of the reserve police unit.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.10  CITY MANAGER SHALL PRESCRIBE TYPE OF UNIFORM.
   The City Manager is authorized to prescribe, by the rules and regulations,
the type of uniform or part thereof which shall be worn by members of the
reserve police.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.11  SERVICE SHALL BE VOLUNTARY.
   All services performed by reserve police officers shall be voluntary and
within the city.  Reserve police officers shall be paid annually the amount set
by ordinance.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
§ 35.12  PURPOSE.
   This subchapter is declared by the City Council as an exercise by the city
of its police powers for the protection of public peace, health, property,
safety, and general welfare, and neither the city, an officer appointed under
the provisions of this subchapter, or any individual, firm, partnership,
corporation, or the receiver of trustees or any other agent thereof, who in
good faith, executes any executive order, rule, or regulation promulgated
pursuant to the provisions of this subchapter shall be liable for injury or
damages sustained to person or property as the direct or proximate result of
such action.
(Ord. 18-1968, passed 4-2-68; Am. Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-20-05)
PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS
§ 35.30  CITY MANAGER SHALL EMPLOY NOT MORE THAN THREE PART-TIME OFFICERS.
   The City Manager is authorized to employ not to exceed three suitable
individuals to serve as part-time police officers of the city during periods of
illness or vacation of the regular members of the Police Department and at such
other times as the City Manager deems it necessary to supplement the regular
police force.
(Ord. 28-1962, passed 6-19-62; Am. Ord. 44-1966, passed 9-20-66)
§ 35.31  COMPENSATION.
   (A)   These part-time police officers shall be compensated at the rate set
by ordinance for each hour actually assigned to duty, such payment to be made
at the regular payroll dates of the city upon vouchers duly signed by the Chief
of Police and approved by the City Manager.  Such compensation shall be the
full compensation of the part-time police officers, regardless of the number of
hours for which they may be assigned to duty.
   (B)   The part-time police officers shall not be members of the Police
Relief and Pension Fund; shall not be entitled to sick leave; and shall not be
entitled to vacation periods or any of the other benefits of municipal
employment.
   (C)   The part-time police officers shall hold their employment subject to
the will of the City Manager.
(Ord. 28-1962, passed 6-19-62)
§ 35.32  BOND REQUIRED.
   The part-time police officers shall furnish the usual bond of police
officers.
(Ord. 28-1962, passed 6-19-62)
FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 35.45  FIRE CHIEF; INTEREST IN CITY CONTRACTS.
   Until such time as a Municipal Fire Department is established as provided
for in the Charter, §
6.03 Fire Department, a person appointed Fire Chief by the City Manager, with
the consent of City Council, shall be considered an official and restricted
from having an interest in city contracts.
(Ord. 41-1971, passed 8-16-71)
§ 35.46  FIRE SERVICE STRUCTURE.
   The Fire Department shall be composed of the career, part-time, volunteer,
and/or paid on-call personnel as may be recommended by the City Manager and
approved by resolution of the City Council.  The City Council may contract with
a private fire company to supply volunteer and/or paid on-call personnel, along
with specific support services as recommended by the City Manager and approved
by resolution of the City Council.
(Ord. 34-1969, passed 7-7-69; Am. Ord. 10-1981, passed 5-4-81; Am. Ord. 48-
1981, passed 10-19-81; Am. Ord. 3-1984, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 05-1992, passed
1-21-92)
§ 35.47  CHIEF FIRE EXECUTIVE.
   (A)   The Chief Fire Executive shall be appointed by the City Manager with
the consent of City Council.
   (B)   The Chief Fire Executive shall be responsible for the operation of the
Fire Department.  He/she shall be the commanding officer of all personnel,
including contracted personnel, and shall have control of assignment, training,
stationing, and direction of work of all personnel and department services,
including any contracted by the city.
   (C)   The Chief Fire Executive shall be responsible for such other
activities and duties as may be assigned by the City Manager.
(Ord. 34-1969, passed 7-7-69; Am. Ord. 10-1981, passed 5-4-81; Am. Ord. 48-
1981, passed 10-19-81; Am. Ord. 3-1984, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 05-1992, passed
1-21-92)
§ 35.48  CAREER PERSONNEL.
   (A)   The rates of pay of paid personnel shall be as set by resolution.
   (B)   The career personnel shall be appointed pursuant to
Chapter 38, Civil Service Rules and Regulations.
(Ord. 34-1969, passed 7-7-69; Am. Ord. 10-1981, passed 5-4-81; Am. Ord. 48-
1981, passed 10-19-81; Am. Ord. 3-1984, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 05-1992, passed
1-21-92)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 36.01  PURPOSE.
   (A)   Subject to approval, disapproval, or modification by City Council, the
Commission shall prescribe, amend, and enforce administrative rules for the
purpose of carrying out the functions, powers, and duties vested in and imposed
upon the Commission by the appropriate sections of the Constitution and
statutes of the State of Ohio and Charter and ordinances of the City of Forest
Park.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (B)   It is the purpose of these rules to supplement, interpret, and
otherwise give effect to Charter, Article XI.  These rules shall be applied in
accordance with the purposes of that article.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-20-70)
   (C)   Except as indicated in the supplemental rules pertaining exclusively
to the Winton Woods School District, these rules shall apply to positions
within the classified service of that School District.  Whenever the term CITY
is used in these rules, it shall mean in addition the School District. 
Whenever the term APPOINTING AUTHORITY or CITY MANAGER is used, it shall mean
the Superintendent of Schools with regard to positions within the School
District.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have
the following meanings ascribed them respectively.
   (A)    APPOINTING AUTHORITY.  The City Manager.
   (B)    CIVIL SERVICE.  Those offices and positions of trust or employment in
the service of the city which are not specifically excluded from coverage by
the City Charter.
   (C)    CITY SERVICE.  All offices and positions in the service of the city.
   (D)    CLASS or CLASSIFICATION.  A group of positions established under
these rules sufficiently similar with respect to duties, responsibilities, and
qualification requirements to be designated by the same descriptive title and
equitably compensated within the same salary scale.
   (E)    CLASSIFIED SERVICE.  The competitive classified civil service of the
city.
   (F)    COMMISSION.  The Municipal Civil Service Commission of the city.
   (G)    CONTINUOUS SERVICE.  Service not broken by resignation or dismissal
without reinstatement within one year of the date of separation.
   (H)   ELIGIBILITY LIST.  A list of names of persons who have been found
qualified, through suitable tests, for employment in positions allocated to a
specified class, arranged in the order of merit.
   (I)   EMPLOYEE.  Any person holding a position subject to appointment,
removal, promotion, or reduction by an appointing officer.
      (1)   COOPERATIVE STUDENT EMPLOYEE.  An employee who is regularly
enrolled in an accredited educational institution and who  is working in the
employ of the city or school district in furtherance of his education.  Such
employee shall be considered UNCLASSIFIED.
      (2)   EMERGENCY EMPLOYEE.  Any employee whose services are required in
case of an emergency for a period not to exceed thirty (30) calendar days. 
Such employee shall be considered UNCLASSIFIED.  (Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
      (3)   REGULAR EMPLOYEE.
         (a)   REGULAR FULL-TIME EMPLOYEE.  Any employee in the civil service
who has been regularly appointed after serving a probationary period to a
position normally involving continuous year- round service, and at the number
of hours per week considered standard at that time.
         (b)   REGULAR PART-TIME EMPLOYEE.  Any employee appointed to a
position normally involving continuous year-round service but working less than
the number of hours in the standard work week.  Such employee shall be
considered unclassified.  (Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
      (4)   PROVISIONAL EMPLOYEE.  Any employee temporarily filling a position
without competition pending the establishment of an eligibility list.  Such
employee shall be considered UNCLASSIFIED.
      (5)   SEASONAL EMPLOYEE.  Any employee whose services are required only
during certain parts of each year, such a position being intermittent or broken
in its nature.  Such employee shall be considered UNCLASSIFIED.
      (6)   STUDENT EMPLOYEE.  An employee who is regularly enrolled in an
accredited educational institution who is working part-time.  Such employee
shall be considered UNCLASSIFIED.
      (7)   TEMPORARY EMPLOYEE.  Any employee appointed for a specified period,
for a special project, or one who is replacing a regular employee on leave. 
Such employee shall be considered UNCLASSIFIED.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (J)   HUMAN RESOURCES DIRECTOR.  The Human Resources Director or such person
as the City Manager may designate.
   (K)   NEW POSITION.  A position created through the authorized addition to
an organization unit of a position not previously existent or a position
created through an authorized change by the Civil Service Commission in
classification.
   (L)   POSITION.  When used by itself shall refer to any specific office,
employment, or job calling for the performance of certain duties, either full
time or part time and for the exercise of certain responsibilities by one
individual.
   (M)   POSITION CLASSIFICATION.  The arrangement of positions into classes
including ranges.  Positions shall be classified in accordance with the duties
and responsibilities of the position.
   (N)   PROMOTION.  A transfer made in accordance with these rules from a
lower class to a higher class involving an increase in responsibilities, a
change in classification title, and the application of a higher salary scale.
   (O)   UNCLASSIFIED SERVICE.  Those offices and positions of trust or
employment who are exempt from any civil service provisions by §
11.04 of the City Charter.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 62-1981, passed 1-4-82; Am. Ord. 9-1982,
passed 4-19-82; Am. Ord.  10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-
12)
§ 36.03  COMMISSION ORGANIZATION.
   (A)   The Commission shall be composed of five (5) persons who shall be
appointed and shall serve in the manner provided by §
11.01 of the City Charter.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of each member of the Commission to attend all
meetings of the Commission, and to devote as much time as is necessary to the
management of the business and affairs of the Commission.
   (C)   The Commission shall elect one (1) of its members as Chairperson, and
one (1) as Vice-Chairperson, who shall serve until a new member is appointed
and qualified (or upon the reappointment of an old member) at which time
successors as Chairperson and Vice- Chairperson shall be elected.  (Ord. 10-
1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (D)   The city may employ a suitable person to serve as Secretary of the
Commission.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.04  AFFIRMATIVE ACTION POLICY.
   (A)   It is the policy of the city to develop and maintain an affirmative
action program designed to provide and promote equal opportunity for all
employees and applicants without regard to race, color, religion, sex, age or
national origin.
   (B)   It is the policy of the city to comply with all federal and state laws
regarding discriminatory practices in recruiting, selection, promotion,
compensation, and other conditions of employment, except where age or sex are
essential bona fide occupational requirements.
   (C)   It is the policy of the city to require parties contracting with the
city to participate along with the city in furthering equal employment
opportunity.
   (D)   The Human Resources Director is designated as the equal employment
opportunity officer of the city with the responsibility to develop a plan, with
the concurrence of City Council, implement and monitor a program to ensure
compliance with this section.  He/she shall develop criteria so as to measure
the effectiveness and results of the program and shall report these results to
the City Council annually.  He/she shall further ensure that the purpose and
scope of this section is appropriately communicated and uniformly applied
throughout all agencies of the city.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 3-1-76; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
COMMISSION POWERS AND DUTIES
§ 36.05  POWERS AND DUTIES OF COMMISSION.
   The Commission shall exercise the following powers and perform the following
duties and functions:
   (A)   To approve and/or amend specifications descriptive of duties,
responsibilities, requirements and desirable qualifications of the various
classifications of positions in the city service.
   (B)   To hear appeals, as provided by law, of employees in the classified
city service relative to reduction in pay or position, layoff, suspension,
discharge, assignment or reassignment to a new or different position
classification, promotional examination, rejection of application, or
performance evaluation rating.  (Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (C)   To enter into agreements with the Civil Service Commission of another
municipality, the State of Ohio Department of Personnel, or to engage a
professional testing agency to conduct examinations for positions in the
classified city service.
   (D)   To appoint a secretary and such examiners, inspectors, clerks, and
other assistants as are necessary in the exercise of the powers and performance
of the duties and functions which the Commission is by law authorized and
required to exercise and perform and to prescribe the duties of all such
employees.
   (E)   To adopt and promulgate rules and regulations, in accordance with the
provisions of the applicable sections of the Ohio Revised Code, relating to the
procedure of the Commission in administering the laws which it has authority or
duty to administer.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.06  ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   The Commission shall direct the administration and enforcement of the State
of Ohio Civil Service Law and of its own rules. Whenever the Commission shall
have reason to believe that any officer, board, commission, or person concerned
with appointment, layoff, suspension or removal, has abused such power by
making or recommending any action in violation of the Civil Service Law or
these rules, it shall be the duty of the Commission to make an investigation,
and if it shall find that a violation of the provisions or intent and spirit of
law or rules has occurred, it shall make a report thereof to the chief
appointing authority involved, who shall have the power to remove forthwith the
guilty officer, board, commission, or person.  An opportunity of being publicly
heard in person or by counsel in his/her own defense shall first be given to
the officer, board, commission, or person.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.07  APPEARANCE BEFORE COMMISSION.
   Whenever an individual or group has a matter which requires or might require
the consideration or decision of the Commission, such individual or group shall
first confer with the Secretary, who shall make the necessary arrangements to
bring such matters before the Commission in regular session.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.08  CIVIL SERVICE SECRETARY.
   The Civil Service Secretary, subject to the approval of the Commission,
shall attend all meetings of the Commission and keep the minutes thereof; shall
keep in the form of a minute record the official actions of the Commission;
shall be at the office of the Commission during the prescribed hours that the
office is open; shall accurately and properly keep all the records of the
Commission; shall keep all files in proper order; shall prepare and deliver or
cause to be delivered, notices and other communications ordered by the
Commission; shall properly furnish appointing authorities with eligibility
lists; shall maintain an official roster; shall handle such correspondence as
the Commission shall determine; shall prepare, conduct, and grade all
competitive and noncompetitive examinations for positions in the classified
city service; shall prepare eligibility lists containing the names of persons
qualified for appointment to positions in the classified city service; shall
conduct research when necessary relative to composing exams for positions in
the classified city service; and shall perform such other duties as may be
required by the Commission.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.09  CIVIL SERVICE CHAIRPERSON.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chairperson to call such meetings of the
Commission as are necessary to transact the business and affairs of the
Commission, and to preside at all meetings of the Commission.
   (B)   The Chairperson may, on his own initiative, and shall, upon the
request of the other four (4)  members of the Commission, call a special
meeting of the Commission to be held not later than ten (10) days from the date
of notice of such meeting.  In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-
Chairperson shall act as Chairperson.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.10  OFFICIAL SIGNATURES.
   The Chairperson of the Commission, or in his/her absence or incapacity, the
Vice-Chairperson, together with the Secretary, shall sign the minutes of the
official acts of the Commission.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.11  QUORUM.
   Three (3) members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum at any meeting
of the Commission, and it shall require the affirmative vote of at least three
(3) members to adopt any motion or resolution.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 62-1981, passed 1-4-82; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
OFFICIAL RECORDS
§ 36.15  COMMISSION MINUTES.
   The Secretary shall keep a minute record of such official actions of the
Commission as are required under these rules. The Commission's minutes shall
record the following matters:
   (A)   Provisional or emergency appointments.
   (B)   Temporary promotions and assignments of employees to work other than
embraced by their classification.
   (C)   Appeals from dismissal, demotion, or suspension.
   (D)   Separation of employees failing to qualify during the probationary
period.
   (E)   Reinstatement of former employees to their positions and replacement
of names on or removal from eligibility lists.
   (F)   Changes in the classification of individual employees and in the
content of the official class specification.
   (G)   Approval of, or changes in, examination schedules and procedures.
   (H)   Appointments of special examiners.
   (I)   Transfers from one department to another.
   (J)   Exemptions from competitive examination in the case of special or
exceptional appointments.
   (K)   Certification from eligibility lists.
   (L)   Result lists of examinations.
   (M)   Any other matters which may be required by the Commission in the
performance of their duties.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.16  OFFICIAL ROSTER.
   The Secretary shall maintain an official roster showing the names and titles
of all employees in the classified service. The Finance Department shall
maintain an official roster showing the rates of pay of all employees in the
classified service.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.17  OTHER RECORDS.
   The Commission shall oversee the maintenance of the official classification,
efficiency records, files of examination papers, correspondence, and other
data.  The examination papers of those who have qualified shall be preserved
until the expiration of the eligibility list on which their names appear, but
the examination papers of those who have failed to qualify may be destroyed
after 60 days from the announcement of the result of the examination.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
CLASSIFIED SERVICE; CLASSIFICATION PLAN
§ 36.20  CLASSIFICATION PLAN.
   The classes of positions described in the “Official Position Classification
and Code Index”, as published with such modifications as may be made thereto
from time to time in accordance with these rules, shall constitute the official
classification plan for all positions in the service of the city.  No person
shall be employed or regularly assigned to work under any title not appropriate
to the duties to be performed.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.21  CLASS SPECIFICATIONS.
   The Commission shall maintain in the Human Resources office a record showing
for each class established the class title, the duties performed, authority,
and the responsibilities involved in each class, the minimum qualifications to
be required of applicants seeking appointment, and the standard scale of
compensation.  The official copy of these specifications shall be endorsed with
the date of adoption and the signature or initials of the Secretary or an
employee authorized to make such endorsement. All amendments to the
specifications adopted under these rules shall be similarly  endorsed.  The
official class specifications shall be open to the public at all times during
the business hours.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.22  SPECIFICATIONS INTERPRETED.
   The specifications of classes of positions in the classification plan are
hereby declared to have the following force and effect:
   (A)   They are descriptive and explanatory and are not restrictive.  The use
of a particular expression or illustration as to duties, qualifications, or
other attributes shall not be held to exclude others not mentioned if such
others are similar in kind or quality nor to limit the power of appointing
authorities to modify or alter the detailed tasks involved in the duties of any
position.  When a substantial change of duties is made, except for a temporary
period or by the addition of duties that are incidental to the main employment,
such change shall be reported to the commission with a view to a possible
reclassification of the position.
   (B)   In determining the allocation of a given position the specifications
shall be considered as a whole.  Consideration shall be given to the general
duties and responsibilities, the examples of duties cited, the minimum entrance
qualifications, and relationships to other classes as affording an exclusive
picture of the employment the class is intended to embrace.  Any example cited,
taken with reference to the general duties statement and the qualifications
required shall not be construed as finally determining whether a position shall
be included within the class.
   (C)   Although they may not be mentioned in the specifications, certain
qualifications which should properly apply to practically all positions, such
as honesty, sobriety, diligence, and compatible physical condition, are taken
for granted. The Commission may prescribe minimum and requirements for
applicants for appointment to particular classes.
(Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.23  ALLOCATION OF POSITIONS TO CLASSES.
   Each position in the civil service shall be classified by the Commission
upon recommendation of the City Manager by allocation to the appropriate
class.  The allocation of positions in the unclassified service but controlled
through compensation ordinance or resolutions on the part of the City Council
or independent boards shall be as determined after conference with the
appointing authorities involved.  The allocation of any position to its
appropriate class shall involve the adoption of the class title for all
positions in the class in payroll records, in requests to the Commission for
the certification of eligible, and in all similar employment processes and
documents.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.24  (RESERVED).
§ 36.25  CLASSIFICATION OF NEW POSITIONS.
   Whenever a new classified position is established, the appointing authority
shall report such fact to the Commission and transmit a comprehensive
description of the duties.  The Commission shall thereupon investigate the
actual or suggested duties and qualification requirements and classify or
reclassify the position by allocating it to its appropriate class in accordance
with the classification plan.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.26  RECLASSIFICATION OF POSITIONS.
   The Commission reserves the right to initiate and conduct investigations of
positions in the classified service as such inquiry becomes necessary, and to
propose changes in classification when the facts are considered to warrant such
action.
   (A)   In this connection, the Commission may at any time secure from the
appointing authority or employees involved, new statements of the duties and
responsibilities of the positions under consideration. The appointing authority
and employees concerned shall have an opportunity to be heard before the
revised classification is approved by the Commission.
      Whenever the allocation of a position to a new or different class has
been authorized, the Commission, after conferring with the appointing authority
concerned,shall determine whether the position of the new class shall continue
to be held by the incumbent of the position of the old class through
examination or otherwise, or be filled through a competitive examination. 
Whenever by reason of reorganization of one or more departments, divisions, or
bureaus of the city service, one or more employees in the unclassified service
are not needed or their positions are abolished in such unclassified service,
they or any of them, with the approval of the City Manager and the Commission,
may be transferred to positions with similar duties in the classified service,
in the same or other department, division, or bureau.
      Only employees who have occupied such unclassified service positions for
two (2) years or more may be so transferred to the classified service. 
However, no such transfer shall be made to a position occupied by a regularly
appointed employee in the classified service or to a position for which an
employee is on a preferred eligibility list by reason of layoff.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.27  AMENDMENT OF CLASSIFICATION PLAN.
   The Commission as it may from time to time deem necessary and after
conference with the appointing authorities involved, may establish new classes,
abolish, merge or divide existing classes and amend the class specifications to
meet changing conditions.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.28  EMPLOYEE RECORD.
   The Human Resources Director shall maintain such employee records as are
necessary to the accomplishment of the various provisions of these rules and
regulations.  These records shall include a central roster of positions and the
record of employment of each employee in the municipal service, including rate
of service, positions held, rate of compensation, vacation, sick leave earned,
and taken, and other such information as may be deemed appropriate by the
Commission.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
PAY RANGES; PAY PLAN
§ 36.30  (RESERVED).
§ 36.31  PROMOTION AND RECLASSIFICATION.
   (A)   Special assignments.  When a department finds it necessary to place an
employee in a special assignment, such as in charge of a group of other
employees, or to perform special work, it shall request a job study in order to
obtain Commission approval.
   (B)   The Commission determines whether a change from one class to another
is a promotion or a reclassification.  Generally speaking, a change is a
promotion if it results from a promotional examination or from the Commission's
action to promote a person without an examination in the absence of
competition.  A reclassification is usually a change from one title to another
without a change in pay.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.32  (RESERVED).
APPLICATION FOR ENTRANCE EXAMINATIONS
§ 36.40  SECRETARY TO DECIDE WHERE EXAMINATIONS ARE TO BE HELD.
   Examinations may be held at such places as the Secretary deems advisable and
shall be administered under the Secretary’s direction.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 65-1973, passed 1-7-73; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.41  NOTICE OF EXAMINATIONS.
   (A)   Notice of competitive entrance examinations (open to persons employed
in the civil service and to those who have not been so employed) to be held
shall be given by advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation and by
posting notices conspicuously at the city municipal building, on official
bulletin boards, and in such other places and through such other media as the
Human Resources Director deems advisable, not less than two (2) weeks prior to
the examinations.
   (B)   The requirement for notice of examinations may be waived by the
Commission in the case of special examinations for positions in connection with
which there is substantial difficulty in obtaining qualified applicants and for
which nonassembled examinations are found necessary.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.42  APPLICATION FORMS.
   (A)   Applications shall be made on forms provided by the Commission.  These
forms shall require the applicant, under  oath or affirmation, to state name,
address, and other information as may reasonably be required concerning
education, experience, health, physical and mental capacity, and felony
conviction record.  (Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (B)   All applications shall be completed, signed, and sworn or affirmed to,
and filed in the Human Resources office not later than the date specified in
the announcement of the examination.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 24-1976, passed 6-7-76; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.43  DUTIES OF CIVIL SERVICE SECRETARY.
   The Civil Service Secretary will be responsible for the following:
   (A)   Examination announcements and publicity (unless other suitable
arrangements are made);
   (B)   Determining whether applicants are qualified for the examinations;
   (C)   Notifying applicants when and where to appear for testing;
   (D)   Administering and grading examinations;
   (E)   Furnishing room facilities for testing; and
   (F)   Furnishing applicants any special equipment needed.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.44  PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   The candidate shall be required to pass a physical examination, and shall be
certified as qualified in such respect before appointment unless the candidate
has successfully passed a physical examination within the last six (6) months
prior to his/her appointment; a copy of the results of said physical
examination must be provided to the Human Resources office prior to the
candidate's appointment. Any employee of the city who desires to transfer to a
highly physically demanding position within the classified service of the city
may be required to successfully pass another physical examination.
   (A)   Where a physical examination is required, that requirement shall be
published in the examination notice.
   (B)   When required by the city, an applicant must furnish the certificate
of a licensed physician who has personal knowledge, either from medical
treatment or from examination, as to the applicant's physical condition.
   (C)   In all physical examinations, the city reserves the right to designate
the examining licensed physician, whose report shall be final.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 65-1973, passed 1-7-74; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.45  COMMISSION TO RULE ON AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   The Commission may establish minimum age limits for each examination.  Age
limits, however, may be waived, at the discretion of  the Commission, for
employees of the  civil service who wish to compete in open competitive
examinations, for which they have the necessary qualifications.  The Secretary
may accept applications of persons under the minimum age limit if in his/her
judgment the eligibility list will not be posted before such applicant reaches
the minimum age limit.  An applicant will be deemed to be within the age limits
for an examination if he/she is within the age limits any time within the month
in which the examination is held.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.46  COMMISSION TO RULE ON EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   The Commission may establish general or specialized educational requirements
for open competitive examinations for any position that falls under the
jurisdiction of the Civil Service Commission. Educational requirements,
however, may be waived by the Commission for candidates who wish to compete in
open competitive examinations for which they are otherwise qualified.
(Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.47  REJECTION OF APPLICATION.
   The Personnel Human Resources Director may, subject to appeal to the
Commission, reject any application for cause, among which the following shall
be sufficient:
   (A)   The applicant lacks any of the minimum qualifications set forth in the
official classification.
   (B)   The applicant is not within the minimum prescribed age limits.
   (C)   The applicant does not meet the physical requirements of the position
to which he/she seeks appointment, is addicted to the excessive use of drugs,
or intoxicating beverages, has been guilty of a crime or of immoral conduct, or
has been dismissed from or disciplined while in previous employment for
flagrant delinquency or misconduct.
   (D)   The applicant has made a false statement in his/her application with
regard to any material fact.
   (E)   The applicant was previously in the classified service in the same or
any other type of employment and was removed for cause and did not resign in
good standing.
   (F)   The applicant, after notification, did not promptly present himself/
herself at the time and place designated for the examination.
   (G)   The Commission has rejected the applicant within the past six (6)
months for any examination because of poor work record, or has rejected the
applicant for the same or similar classification because of arrest record, or
has rejected the applicant for the same or similar classification for failing
to meet the minimum qualifications set forth in the official announcement,
unless the applicant has accrued the required qualifications during that
period.
   (H)   The applicant failed or was disqualified from an examination for the
same or similar classification within the preceding six (6) months.  However,
an applicant who is disqualified for medical reasons only, may compete upon
presentation of medical evidence that the condition causing the
disqualification has been corrected.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 06-2011, passed 6-6-11; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.48  AGE LIMITATIONS PERTAINING TO POLICE OFFICERS AND FIREFIGHTERS.
   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment to the Police
Department or Fire Department, as a  police officer or  firefighter, subject 
to the civil service laws of the city unless the person has reached the age of
21 for police officer positions and the age of 18 for firefighter positions and
has passed a physical examination, given by a licensed physician, showing that
the person meets the physical requirements necessary to perform the duties of a
police officer or firefighter as established by the Commission having
jurisdiction over the appointment.  The appointing authority shall file with
the Police and Firefighters' Disability and Pension Fund a copy of the report
or findings of the licensed physician.  The professional fee for this physical
examination shall be paid by the city.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 36-1970, passed 3-16-70; Am. Ord. 57-
1976, passed 11-1-76; Am. Ord. 32-1996, passed 1-6-97; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed
5-7-12)
ENTRANCE EXAMINATIONS
§ 36.50  COMMISSION SHALL PREPARE AND THE SECRETARY SHALL ADMINISTER ALL
EXAMINATIONS.
   The Commission will cause to be prepared and the Secretary shall administer
all examinations for positions in the classified civil service of the city.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-20-70; Am. Ord. 65-1973, passed 1-7-74; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.51  EXAMINATIONS TO BE PRACTICAL.
   The Commission will select the most appropriate examination available which
will fairly test the relative capacity of the person examined to discharge the
particular duties of the class of positions to which appointment is sought.
   (A)   The examination will include a written test in each case. If none is
available, or if a special test is required, the Commission will be notified.
   (B)   When appropriate and deemed advisable by the Commission, tests of
physical qualifications, health, performance, and manual skill may be included.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 65-1973, passed 1-7-74; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.52  CONTENT OF EXAMINATIONS.
   The fitness tests held to establish an eligibility list for any class shall
consist of one or more of the following parts.
   (A)   Written test.  This part shall include a written demonstration
designed to show the familiarity of competitors with the knowledge involved in
the class of positions to which they seek appointment, their ability in the use
of English, the range of their general information, or their general
educational attainments.  A formal thesis upon one or more subjects may be
required if advisable.
   (B)   Oral test.  This part when required shall include an oral test with
competitors for classes of positions where ability to deal with others, to meet
the public, or other personal qualifications are to be determined.  An oral
test may also be used in examinations where a written test is unnecessary or
impracticable.
(Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (C)   Performance tests.  This part when required shall include such tests
of performance or trade as will determine the ability and manual skill of
competitors to perform the work involved.
   (D)   Physical evaluation. This part when required shall consist of tests of
bodily condition, muscular strength, agility, and physical fitness, of
competitors.  This may be given a weight in examinations or may be used in
excluding from further examination applicants who do not measure up to the
minimum required standards.  (Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83)
   (E)   Psychological tests.  This part, when required, shall include any
tests to determine mental alertness, the general capacity of applicants to
adjust their thinking to new problems and conditions of life, or to ascertain
special character traits and aptitudes.
(Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.53  (RESERVED).
§ 36.54  METHOD OF RATING EXAMINATIONS.
   (A)   Each part of the examination for any class, except in such cases where
the passing of a physical examination is a prerequisite, shall be separately
rated and the proficiency of each competitor in each part rated on a scale of
100 for the maximum possible attainment and 70 for the required minimum rating
(or for passing).
   (B)   Tie grades among veterans and among nonveterans will be broken by the
priority of filing application, as indicated by a time and date stamp.  The
names of the applicants receiving an average of 70 or more shall be posted in
the Human Resources office and entered on the appropriate eligibility list. 
The name of any applicant failing to qualify shall not be made public.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 10-1983, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.55  (RESERVED).
§ 36.56  EMPLOYEE PREFERENCE.
   (A)   Any person who is employed by the city as a regular full- time
employee, regular part-time employee, or is a member of the Forest Park
auxiliary police department shall file with the Commission a certificate or
other authentic proof of continuous service, whereupon he/she shall receive
additional credit given in any open examination in which he/she receives a
passing grade in the following manner.  (Ord. 9-1982, passed 4-19-82)
 
Months Points
12     l
24     3
36     5
 
   (B)   The above points are to apply to any regular full-time or regular
part-time employee of the city who successfully completes and obtains a passing
grade in an open examination for another position in the city.  (Ord. 9-1982,
passed 4-19-82)
   (C)   The provisions set forth in §
36.56(A) shall apply to the existing and future eligibility lists prepared by
the Secretary.
   (D)   In no event shall the combined total point preference awarded under §
36.56(A) be in excess of five (5) points.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 55-1973, passed 10-1-73; Am. Ord. 39-
1979, passed 9-17-79; Am. Ord. 62-1983, passed 1-4-83; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed
5-7-12)
§ 36.565  VETERAN'S PREFERENCE.
   (A)   Veteran's preference points are provided only on the entrance
examinations for the City of Forest Park and the Winton Woods School District.
An applicant who has served in the military is eligible for the addition of
extra points to his/her passing examination score if he/she meets one (1) of
the following conditions:
      (1)   The applicant has served on active military duty for more than one
hundred eighty (180) days in the Armed Forces (other than the Reserves or
National Guard) and has been discharged or released from the military under
honorable or general conditions;
      (2)   The applicant has served on active military duty as a member of a
Reserve component during a period of war or in an expedition for which a
campaign badge was authorized and has been discharged or released from the
military under honorable or general conditions; or
      (3)   The applicant was a member of a Reserve component of the U.S.
military (including Army or Air National Guard) who served on active military
duty for a period of more than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days any
part of which occurred after September 11, 2001, and was discharged or released
for such duty under honorable or general conditions.
      (4)   If an applicant meets one of the conditions as stated in division
(1), (2), or (3) above, and is able to document his/her eligibility as stated,
five (5) points will be added to his/her final passing examination score.
      (5)   Any applicant who has established veteran status as defined above,
and who has the present existence of a service- connected disability rated ten
percent (10%) or higher, as determined by the Department of Veterans Affairs or
by the applicable military service, may be eligible for disabled veteran's
preference points. A total of ten (10) points will be added to the applicant's
final passing score if he/she documents their eligibility.
      (6)   Applicants who wish to be awarded veteran's preference points or
disabled veteran's preference points must complete the military service box on
the employment application at the time it is filed. Proof of military service
or disability must be submitted to the Commission Secretary on or before the
date of the written test. Proof of military service or disability will not be
accepted after the written test starts. Acceptable documentation of proof of
military service is as follows:
         (a)   A Form DD214, indicating the branch or service, character of
discharge and enlistment dates; or
         (b)   A Service Information Letter or comparable documentation which
certifies the applicant's military dates and discharge status from the Veterans
Administration Office, 420 North James Road, Columbus, Ohio 43219; (614) 388-
7014.
         (c)   Disabled veterans only must also submit, in addition to the
DD214 form, an award letter from the Department of Veterans' Affairs or
applicable military service, stating the percent of service-connected
disability.
(Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12; Am. Ord. 17-2016, passed 12-5-16)
ELIGIBILITY LISTS
§ 36.57  POSTING OF LISTS.
   From the results of each examination, the Secretary shall prepare and keep
open to public inspection an eligibility list of the persons whose average
grade in the examination for the class is not less than 70 and who are
otherwise eligible. These persons shall be notified and take rank upon the
eligibility list in the order of their relative grades without reference to
priority of time of examination.  Whenever it becomes necessary to hold a
subsequent examination in order to obtain additional eligible, the Commission
may consolidate existing lists for the same class by rearranging the eligible
names therein according to their grades. Each person whose name appears on an
existing list which is to be merged with a new list shall have an opportunity
to compete in the second examination, and his/her standing on the eligibility
list shall then be determined by his/her grade on the subsequent examination.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.58  DURATION OF LISTS.
   The term of eligibility of each list and the names appearing thereon shall
be fixed by the Commission at not less than one (1) year nor more than three
(3) years.  Any list that has been in effect for more than one (1) year may be
abolished at any time required in the public interest.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 62-1981, passed 1-4-82; Am. Ord. 04-
2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.59  TRANSFER TO LOWER CLASS.
   The name of any eligible may at any time, upon his written request, be
transferred to the eligibility list for a lower class requiring qualifications
of the same general character.  He/she shall be ranked thereon according to his
grade.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.60  REMOVAL FROM LIST.
   The name of any person appearing on an eligibility list who fails to report
for an interview with the appointing authority, who fails to respond to a
notice from the Secretary, who declines an appointment without reasons
satisfactory to the Human Resources Director, or who cannot be located by the
postal authorities, shall be removed from the eligibility list.  The eligible
shall be notified to this effect unless his/her whereabouts are unknown.  His/
her name may be reinstated on the eligibility list only in case a thoroughly
satisfactory explanation of the circumstances is made to the Human Resources
Director.  In case an eligible's name appears on more than one list, a
permanent appointment to a position in one class shall cause his/her name to be
removed from other eligibility lists for classes the salary of which is equal
or lower.  If the eligibility list in question has resulted from a promotional
examination, resignation from the service shall be cause for removal from the
eligibility list.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.61  DISQUALIFICATION OF ELIGIBLES AND EMPLOYEES ON LAYOFF LISTS.
   If at any time after the creation of an eligibility list or layoff list, the
Commission has reason to believe that any person whose name appears on any list
is disqualified for appointment or recall because of any of the following
listed reasons developed subsequent to his/her examination or any layoff, such
person shall be notified and given an opportunity to be heard.  If such person
shall fail to appear for hearing, or upon his/her being heard, fail to satisfy
the Commission, his/her name shall be removed from the appropriate list.
   (A)   Incapacity, either physical or mental.
   (B)   Errors disclosed in computing his/her scores.
   (C)   False statements made in his/her application.
   (D)   Personal activity in violation of the rules of the Commission.
   (E)   Any other similar reason.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
§ 36.62  CHANGE OF ADDRESS.
   Each person on an eligibility list shall file with the Secretary written
notice of any change of address, and failure to do so may cause his/her name to
be removed from the eligibility list.
(Ord. 16-1970, passed 3-2-70; Am. Ord. 04-2012, passed 5-7-12)
APPOINTMENTS TO THE COMPETITIVE SERVICE
§ 36.65  CERTIFICATION PROCESS.
   (A)   Immediately on receipt of a written request for certification to fill
a vacancy, the Commission shall certify to the appointing officer from the
eligibility list most nearly appropriate, the names, addresses, and rank of all
persons scoring 90 or more.  If such list does not contain a minimum of ten
