EXCAVATIONS
§ 92.01  WRITTEN APPLICATION REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person, public agency, or company, except in emergency situations,
shall make or cause to be made any excavation or opening in any paved street,
sidewalk, curb and gutter, or in the unpaved portion of the right-of-way in the
city without first submitting a written application to the City Manager or his
designated representative, stating the work desired to be done and the
estimated time and cost of the improvement.  When any emergency situation
exists, the person or company making or causing to be made the excavation or
opening shall submit the application during the next normal day of business of
the city.
   (B)   The City Manager or his designated representative shall approve all
work and issue all permits.  Except in emergency situations, no work shall
begin without the approval of the City Manager or his designated
representative.
   (C)   Any homeowner or property owner making normal repairs on his existing
sidewalk or driveway approaches need not pay the permit fee charge or be
required to make an advance deposit, but shall be required to obtain a street
opening permit and comply with all other provisions of this chapter.  If the
normal repairs on sidewalks or driveway approaches are made by any person or
company other than the homeowner or property owner, the person or company
making these repairs shall not be charged a permit fee, but must obtain a
permit and make an advance deposit, before any work is started.
(Ord. 35-1970, passed 5-4-70; Am. Ord. 43-1976, passed 9-7-76)  Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.02  PERMIT FEE.
   (A)   A permit fee as listed in
Chapter 156, Comprehensive Fee Schedule, shall be charged for the issuance of
each such permit.  The permit fee will allow one hour of inspection time.  If
more than one hour is accumulated, the person or contractor shall be charged at
the rate of inspection fees listed in
Chapter 156 for the actual time spent on the job by the city's inspector over
one hour.  The city retains the right to deduct any extra inspection charges
from the deposit prior to returning it to the permit holder.  In addition to
the permit fee, any person who desires to make or cause to be made an opening
in the streets, sidewalks, concrete curb and gutter, or right-of-way must
deposit cash or a satisfactory bond payable to the city to guarantee that the
surface of the street, sidewalk, concrete curb and gutter, or right-of-way so
opened will be restored to the satisfaction of the City Manager within a one-
year period.  The permit holder is responsible for the maintenance of the site
for a period of one year after restoration has been completed.  Such deposits
shall be as listed in
Chapter 156, Comprehensive Fee Schedule (see §
156.14).
   (B)   After the work has been approved by the City Manager and prior to
return of any deposits, the permit holder must deposit with the city an amount
equal to 50% of the deposit provided above for restoration as a maintenance
guarantee.  This deposit, less any moneys expended by the city on maintenance,
shall be returned upon application by the permit holder.  If not requested for
return within 18 months the entire amount will be returned to the General Fund
of the city.  Any maintenance must be accomplished by the permit holder within
ten days or the city will do the work and deduct from the deposit.
(Ord. 35-1970, passed 5-4-70; Am. Ord. 9-1986, passed 5-5-86)  Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.03  OPENING OR EXCAVATION REQUIREMENTS.
   The following general requirements will apply to all persons who make or
cause to be made any opening or excavation in any of the streets, sidewalks, or
rights-of-way within the city:
   (A)   All street and curb cuts must be outlined first with a diamond point
saw which will insure a neat patch.
   (B)   All excess material excavated must be hauled away from the site.
   (C)   All backfill must be granular backfill well compacted to paving
subgrade.
   (D)   Paving must be replaced with a similar material to that removed and in
the unpaved areas, the surface should be left in comparable condition to that
prior to such excavation.
   (E)   Any such opening within the right-of-way shall be adequately fenced,
signed and lighted.  Fences, signs and lights shall be securely and
conspicuously placed in or near such excavations, one at each end of the space
so excavated and if the opening exceeds 20 feet in length, the person making
such excavation or causing same to be made shall cause additional warning
devices to be placed for each additional 20 feet in length or portion thereof
so excavated or open and shall keep lights burning the entire night.  Lights
must be flashing yellow lights or other similar warning devices. Traffic-
control warning signs required shall be determined by the City Manager.  Signs
and lights shall conform to the Uniform Code of Traffic Control of the state.
(Ord. 35-1970, passed 5-4-70)  Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.04  REFUND OF DEPOSITS.
   Upon notification from the Public Works Director that any opening so made
has been satisfactorily closed and restored, the Finance Director shall refund
to the person who posted the same the deposits specified in §
92.02.  If upon inspection by the Public Works Director, he finds such opening
not to be properly closed and restored, he shall give the person making such
excavation or the one who caused the excavation to be made notice to restore
the surface to his satisfaction within a period of five days or the city will
do so and charge the expense against the deposit so posted.
(Ord. 35-1970, passed 5-4-70)
SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR
§ 92.10  PURPOSE; STATE OF DISREPAIR AND NUISANCE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   The terms of §§
92.10 through
92.17 shall be construed for the benefit of the public using of the sidewalks,
driveway approaches, and crosswalks but shall not be arbitrary as against the
property owner.
   (B)   A state of disrepair and nuisance shall be considered such condition
as would prevent the safe use of the public sidewalk, driveway approach, and
crosswalk hereinafter set forth.
      (1)   A raise or depression between sections in the sidewalk, driveway
approach, or crosswalk in excess of 1 inch.
      (2)   Loose, broken portions of concrete in the sidewalk, driveway
approach, or crosswalk which provides an unstable walking area or broken
portions which have been removed from the sidewalk, driveway approach, or
crosswalk.
      (3)   Areas of sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk that have been
caused to sink or tilt from its normal position due to undermining or sinking
of subsurface that provides unsafe walking conditions
      (4)   Areas of sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk that have become
broken, raised, or tilted by roots of trees to such extent that the public
safety would be affected.
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71; Am. Ord. 19-1985, passed  - -85; Am. Ord. 28-
1996, passed 12-2-96)
§ 92.11  OWNERS OF ABUTTING PROPERTY TO KEEP SIDEWALKS IN REPAIR.
   (A)   Where land abuts on a street where there is a paved sidewalk or abuts
on a crosswalk or driveway approach, the owner of such land shall be jointly
and severally responsible for causing the paved sidewalk, driveway approach, or
crosswalk abutting such land to be kept in repair and free from nuisance. 
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71; Am. Ord. 19-1985, passed  - -85)
§ 92.12  NOTICE OF REPAIR.
   (A)   When the City Manager finds that such sidewalk, driveway approach, or
crosswalk is in a state of disrepair or is not free from nuisance, he shall
notify the owner of the abutting property, in writing, to have the necessary
construction, reconstruction, or repair made.  This notice shall be served on
the owner or his agent, personally or by registered mail sent to the last known
address of the owner and by leaving a copy of the notice with the occupant of
the premises if occupied or left in a conspicuous place on the premises if
unoccupied.  For purposes of such service, any person charged with the
collection of rents or payment of taxes on the property or having general
control of it in any way shall be considered the agent of the owner. 
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71; Am. Ord. 19-1985, passed  -  -85)
§ 92.13  CONTENTS OF NOTICE.
   The notice provided for in §
92.12 shall identify the property and give the location of the sidewalk,
driveway approach, or crosswalk and the period of time allowed the property
owner to have the work done.  Such time shall be reasonable, but shall not be
less than 15 days for construction and not less than five days for repairs.
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71; Am. Ord. 19-1985, passed  - -85)
§ 92.14  EMERGENCIES.
   In case of emergency, the City Manager is authorized to have temporary
repairs made, or to barricade and red-light the area, or otherwise provide for
the public safety.  The reasonable cost of emergency repair and protection
shall be charged against the abutting property and shall be collected as
provided for in §§
92.15 and
92.16.
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-7l; Am. Ord. 19-1985, passed  - -85)
§ 92.15  PROPERTY OWNERS TO BE BILLED.
   Upon completion by the city of any sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk
repair, construction, or reconstruction as provided for in §§
92.13 and
92.14, the owner of the abutting property, or his agent, shall be billed for
the reasonable cost and expense of the work.  The bill shall include:
   (A)   All construction costs, including emergency.
   (B)   A charge for administrative costs of $5 or 10% of the construction
costs, whichever is greater, not to exceed $35 for all bills and/or outstanding
balances not paid by the due date.
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71; Am. Ord. 19-1985, passed  - -85; Am. Ord. 28-
1992, passed 12-7-92; Am. Ord. 34-1998, passed 1-11-99)
§ 92.16  ASSESSMENT AGAINST ABUTTING PROPERTY.
   Bills issued under §
92.15 shall be payable within 30 days from the date of such bill.  Bills not
paid within 30 days shall be certified to the County Auditor to be an
assessment against the abutting property.
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71)
§ 92.17  APPEAL.
   (A)   A property owner protesting any notice to repair provided for herein
shall file a written notice of appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals prior to
the time set for compliance.  The Board of Zoning Appeals shall hear the
protest as soon as practicable without charge and without requiring public
notice to be given.
   (B)   The Board of Zoning Appeals is authorized to hear evidence and
determine if the provisions of the notice of repair are reasonable.
(Ord. 61-1971, passed 11-15-71)
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
§ 92.20  REPAIRING SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any lot or land abutting upon any
street to refuse, fail, or neglect to repair or keep in repair, the sidewalk in
front of such lot or land after due notice ordering the repair of such sidewalk
pursuant to the notice requirements of §§
92.12 and
92.13.
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-6l; Am. Ord. 70-1972, passed 12-18-72) Penalty, see
§
92.99
§ 92.21  REMOVAL OF LANTERNS AND WARNING BARRICADES.
   The removal of flashing warning lights, fencing, signs, barricades, or other
means placed on the streets and on construction projects, public or private, in
the city as a warning or protection for the public by persons unauthorized to
remove the same, or the willful, careless, or negligent destruction of the
flashing warning lights, fencing, signs or barricades are prohibited.
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-61)  Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.22  SIDEWALKS TO BE CLEANED OF ICE AND SNOW.
   It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of each and every parcel of
real estate in the city abutting upon any sidewalk to keep the sidewalk
abutting his premises free and clear from snow and ice, and to remove all snow
and ice accumulated thereon within a reasonable time, which will ordinarily not
exceed 72 hours, after the abatement of any storm during which the snow and ice
may have accumulated.
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-6l; Am. Ord. 50-1961, passed 12-5-6l; Am. Ord. 52-
1985, passed 12-16-85)  Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.23  RUBBISH ON STREETS, ETC.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited upon
any street or sidewalk debris, stone, soil, rubbish, sand, mud, gravel,
excavating material, coal, coke, construction or building materials, or other
nuisance or obstruction without authorization of the City Manager.
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-61; Am. Ord. 70-1972, passed 12-18-72)  Penalty, see
§
92.99
§ 92.24  ENCUMBERING STREETS.
   Whenever any debris, stone, soil, or any other material is deposited on the
street or sidewalk by reason of any slide, collapse, washing away, or crumbling
of the land or structures occupied by, owned by, or controlled by any person or
corporation, the person or corporation shall remove such debris, stone, soil,
or other material within a reasonable time after written notification and shall
barricade and light the obstruction in the street or sidewalk until complete
removal of such debris, stone, soil, or other material has been effected. 
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-61; Am. Ord. 70-1972, passed 12-18-72) Penalty, see
§
92.99
§ 92.25  ENCUMBERING SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, person, or corporation in
control of any lot or land to refuse, fail, or neglect to keep the sidewalk in
front of such lot or land free from debris, stone, soil, rubbish, sand, mud,
gravel, excavating material, coal, coke, construction or building materials, or
other nuisance or obstruction. 
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-61; Am. Ord. 70-1972, passed 12-18-72) Penalty, see
§
92.99
§ 92.26  NOTIFICATION AND REMOVAL.
   (A)   Unless provided otherwise in §§
92.20 through
92.26, the notice required hereunder shall be sufficient if given by the City
Manager to the person or corporation who is the owner of the lot or land.
      (1)   By mail to the last known address of the person or corporation, or
      (2)   By personal service placing a notice on the premises where the
slide, collapse, washing away, or crumbling occurred.
   (B)   Prior notification by the City Manager ordering removal shall be
required only in those cases where debris, stone, soil, sand, mud, gravel, or
other material is deposited upon the sidewalk or street by reason of any
natural slide, collapse, washing away, or crumbling of the lot or land or the
structures located thereon. However, notification by the City Manager in those
cases will not be required if the owner, occupant, person, or corporation in
control of the lot or land has, within the past one year, been previously
notified by the City Manager of a similar condition existing upon the sidewalk
or street in front of such lot or land.
   (C)   The city is authorized to remove from the sidewalk or street in front
of such lot or land the debris, stone, soil, rubbish, sand, mud, gravel,
excavating material, coal, coke, construction or building material, or other
nuisance or obstruction immediately if no notice is required or within 48 hours
after delivery or mailing of the notice required herein.  In each case where
the city removes the same, the person or corporation owning the lot or land
shall be liable to the city for the expense of removal thereof which cost shall
be over and above any fine that is levied under §
92.99.
(Ord. 21-1961, passed 10-3-61; Am. Ord. 70-1972, passed 12-18-72) Penalty, see
§
92.99
§ 92.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty
of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not exceeding $100.  Each separate
opening and each day the opening continues shall constitute a separate
violation and a separate offense. 
   (B)   No refunds will be made if the amount claimed equals $5 or less. The
foregoing not withstanding, the city manager is granted the discretionary
authority to order a refund, including but not limited to an amount of $5 or
less, where deemed to be reasonable and appropriate.
(Ord. 35-1970, passed 5-4-70; Am. Ord. 03-2006, passed 3-6-06)
CHAPTER 93:  PARKS; RULES AND REGULATIONS
Section
   
93.01   Conduct
   
93.02   Roadways in parks, restricted
   
93.03   Use of parks
 
   
93.99   Penalty
Cross-reference:
   Parks and facilities fees, see §
30.14
§ 93.01  CONDUCT.
   (A)   No person, while using the park or recreational areas and facilities
of the city shall conduct himself in such a manner as to endanger the safety or
life of other persons lawfully using the facilities.
   (B)   No person so using the park or recreational areas and facilities shall
use profane, obscene, or indecent language, or shall act in an obscene or
indecent manner.
   (C)   No person so using the park or recreational areas and facilities shall
use threatening or insulting language or commit any act tending to a breach of
public peace or shall act in a disorderly manner.
   (D)   No person shall disobey a lawful order of the Park and Recreation
Commission or the police, or in any way hinder or prevent them from discharging
their duties.
   (E)   No person shall possess or consume any alcoholic beverages on park
premises.  This prohibition may be waived by issuance of a special permit by
the City Manager or his/her designee.  Such permit may also be revoked by the
City Manager or his/her designee if any abuse of the privilege granted is
either observed or reported and verified.  Violation of this division shall be
considered a misdemeanor of the first degree.
   (F)   No person shall dump litter, bottles, paper, or other refuse on the
park or recreational areas and facilities except into trash containers provided
for such articles.
   (G)   No person shall molest, disturb, injure, or kill any animals, birds,
trees, or other plants, or disturb the ecological environments located within
the park and recreational areas.
   (H)   No person shall damage, destroy, or remove without permission of the
Park and Recreation Commission, any equipment or other property or facility of
the city located within the park or recreational areas and facilities.
(Ord. 27-1972, passed 6-5-72; Am. Ord. 31-1990, passed 11-5-90)  Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.02  ROADWAYS IN PARKS, RESTRICTED.
   (A)   The municipal building's south connecting driveway to the park
facilities shall not be used as an ingress or exit to the park facilities or
high school parking lot.  Use shall be limited to those vehicles coming to and
from and having business in the municipal building complex, and shall not
beused to accommodate through traffic between Waycross Road and West Kemper
Road.
   (B)   The maximum speed limit for all vehicles on park roadways shall be 15
miles per hour.
   (C)   No trucks over 3/4-ton or trailers shall be permitted on the park
roadways without authorization of the City Manager.
   (D)   No person shall park a vehicle along park roadways except in the
designated parking areas.
(Ord. 27-1972, passed 6-5-72)  Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.03  USE OF PARKS.
   (A)   All parks and recreational facilities owned by the city are provided
for the exclusive use of the residents of the city.  Exceptions to this usage
may be authorized by the Park and Recreation Commission in the following
instances:
      (1)   Nonresident athletic teams, when competing against Greenhills-
Forest Park teams or other Forest Park teams, may play games on city-owned
recreational facilities.
      (2)   Use by other nonresident groups may be authorized by the Park and
Recreation Commission when a particular facility is not scheduled in advance
for use by the residents of the city.  When appropriate, a fee will be charged
for the use of the facility to cover necessary maintenance and other
appropriate expense for the time used.
   (B)   The parks, including parking areas, shall be closed to use from dusk
until 6:00 a.m. except as posted or pursuant to an issued permit.  All permits
shall be issued in such a manner as to assure the designation of a responsible
individual.
   (C)   Assignment and scheduling of facilities and issuing of permits for use
of facilities will be made by the Park and Recreation Commission. 
   (D)   Except for events scheduled by the Park and Recreation Commission, the
parks, recreational areas, and recreational facilities shall be available to
residents of the city on a first come-first serve basis, except as otherwise
provided by the Park and Recreation Commission. 
   (E)   Organized resident sports groups may have priority use of all
baseball, softball, and soccer fields and tennis courts located on city-owned
park and recreational facilities during their particular athletic season. 
Requests for usage by the groups shall be submitted in writing to the Park and
Recreation Commission.
(Ord. 27-1972, passed 6-5-72; Am. Ord. 41-1994, passed 10-3-94)  Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Anyone violating the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
such fines as are set forth in the traffic code for traffic and parking
violations and in the general offense code for criminal violations.  Where no
specific section of the traffic and general offense code cover a violation of
this chapter the fine shall be not more than $100 and costs of court.  This
penalty does not include violation of §
93.01(E).
   (B)   No refunds will be made if the amount claimed equals $5 or less. The
foregoing not withstanding, the city manager is granted the discretionary
authority to order a refund, including but not limited to an amount of $5 or
less, where deemed to be reasonable and appropriate.
(Ord. 27-1972, passed 7-5-72; Am. Ord. 31-1990, passed 11-5-90; Am. Ord. 03-
2006, passed 3-6-06)
CHAPTER 94:  DEPOSIT AND DISTRIBUTION OF LITTER AND HANDBILLS

private premises
   
94.11   Litter on occupied private property
   
94.12   Owner to maintain property free of litter
   
94.13   Litter on vacant property
   
94.14   Clearing of litter from open private property by city
   
94.15   Upsetting public or private receptacles
   
94.16   Litter thrown by persons in vehicle
   
94.17   Truck loads causing litter
   
94.18   Dumping
 
   
94.99   Penalty
§ 94.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUTHORIZED PRIVATE RECEPTACLE.  A litter storage and collection receptacle
which is so constructed as to prevent any of its contents from being blown or
deposited upon any public or private property.
   COMMERCIAL HANDBILL.  Any printed or written matter, any sample or device,
circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise
reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature which:
      (1)   Advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, or thing;
or
      (2)   Directs attention to any business, mercantile, or commercial
establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or
indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or
      (3)   Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical
performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is
charged for the purpose of private use or profit. The terms of this definition
shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up
solely for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, the
actual performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, being given or taking
place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not
restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace,
safety, and good order.  However, nothing contained in this clause shall be
deemed to authorize the holding, giving, or taking place of any meeting,
theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, without a license,
where such license may be required by law of this state, or under any ordinance
of this city; or
      (4)   While containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is
predominately and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or
circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any
person so engaged as advertiser or distributor.
   GARBAGE.  Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the
handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food.
   JUNK.  Any worn-out, castoff, or discarded article or material which is
ready for destruction or has been collected or stored for salvage or conversion
to some other use.  Any article of material which, unaltered or unchanged and
without further reconditioning, can be used for its original purpose as readily
as when new, shall not be considered JUNK.
   LITTER.  Garbage, refuse, junk, and rubbish, as defined herein, and all
other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends
to create a danger to public health, safety, and welfare.
   NEWSPAPER.  Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law,
any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States
in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and
recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law, and, in
addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine
regularly published with not less than four issues per year.
   NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILL.  Any printed or written matter, any sample or
device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or
any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of
literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a commercial handbill
or newspaper.
   PARK.  A park, reservation, playground, or any other public area in the
city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation.
   PRIVATE PREMISES.  Any dwelling, house, building, or other structure,
designated or used wholly or in part for private purposes, whether inhabited or
temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard,
grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, or mailbox belonging or
appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure.
   PUBLIC PLACE.  Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, accepted
rights-of-way, or other public ways, any and all public parks, squares, spaces,
grounds, and buildings, and any private property to which members of the public
are customarily and regularly invited or which is frequented by members of the
public on a regular basis.
   REFUSE.  All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body
wastes), including but not limited to garbage, rubbish, ashes, street
cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial
wastes.
   RUBBISH.  Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes, such as, but not limited to, paper, wrappings,
cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding,
crockery, and similar materials.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74; Am. Ord. 35-1987, passed 9-21-87)
§ 94.02  LITTER IN PUBLIC PLACES.
   No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any public place within
the city except in public receptacles, or in authorized private receptacles,
for collection.  In no way shall this section allow for the use of public
receptacles in lieu of the waste collection service for household litter/
refuse.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74; Am. Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.03  PLACEMENT OF LITTER IN RECEPTACLES SO AS TO PREVENT SCATTERING.
   Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private
receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or
deposited by the elements upon any public place or upon any private property.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.04  SWEEPING LITTER INTO GUTTERS PROHIBITED.
   Except as authorized by the City Manager, no person shall sweep into or
deposit in any gutter, street, or other public place within the city the
accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private
sidewalk or driveway.  Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the
sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.05  MERCHANT'S DUTY TO KEEP SIDEWALKS FREE OF LITTER.
   No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or
deposit in any gutter, street, parking lot, or other public place in the city
the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or
private sidewalk or driveway.  Persons owning or occupying places of business
within the city shall keep the sidewalks in front of their business premises
free of litter.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.06  LITTER IN PARKS.
   No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except
in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented
from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or
upon any street or other public place.  Where public receptacles are not
provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park and properly
disposed of elsewhere by the person responsible for its presence.  In no way
shall this section allow for the use of public receptacles in lieu of the waste
collection service for household litter/refuse.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74; Am. Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.07  LITTER IN FOUNTAINS, DRAINAGE EASEMENTS, AND BODIES OF WATER.
   No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, drainage easement,
or any body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.08  THROWING OR DISTRIBUTING HANDBILLS IN PUBLIC PLACES.
   No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in
or upon any sidewalk, street, or other public place within the city.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.09  DEPOSITING COMMERCIAL OR NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILLS ON UNINHABITED OR
VACANT PREMISES.
   No person knowing or having reason to know of the vacancy of private
premises shall throw or deposit any newspaper or commercial or noncommercial
handbill in or upon any private premises which are uninhabited or vacant.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.10  DISTRIBUTING COMMERCIAL OR NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILLS AT INHABITED
PRIVATE PREMISES.
   No person shall deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial
handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited unless such handbill
is so placed or deposited as to prevent such handbill from being blown or
drifted about such premises or onto sidewalks, streets, or other public places,
and except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal
postal law or regulations.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.11  LITTER ON OCCUPIED PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no person shall throw or
deposit litter on any occupied private property of another within the city.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.12  OWNER TO MAINTAIN PROPERTY FREE OF LITTER.
   The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times
maintain the property free of litter.  However, this section shall not prohibit
the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.13  LITTER ON VACANT PROPERTY.
   No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private
property of another within the city.  The City Manager may, at the request of
the property owner or with the property owner's consent, post signs on vacant
private property prohibiting the deposit of litter and stating the penalty, but
such signs shall in no case relieve the property owner from any provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74)  Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.14  CLEARING OF LITTER FROM OPEN PRIVATE PROPERTY BY CITY.
   (A)   Notice to remove.  The City Manager is authorized and empowered to
notify the owner or his agent of any open, occupied, or vacant private property
within the city, to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's
property.  Such notice shall be in writing and shall be sent to the owner at
his last known address by regular mail. Said notice shall serve to put the
recipient on notice with respect to the requirements of this chapter and shall
obviate the need for additional notice for the same or similar violation within
365 days of the date of the notice.
   (B)   Action upon noncompliance.  Upon failure, neglect, or refusal of any
owner or agent so notified to properly dispose of litter within seven days
after the date of the written notice provided for in §
94.14 (A) above, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known
address of such owner or agent, the City Manager is hereby authorized and
empowered to remove or to pay for the removal of such litter, or to order its
disposal by the city.
   (C)   Assessment of costs by city.  When the city has effected the removal
of such litter, or has paid for its removal, then after the work is completed,
the City Manager shall give seven days notice, by regular mail, to the owner of
such property at his last known address to pay the cost of such removal.  The
notice shall be accompanied by a statement of the amount of costs incurred.  In
the event that the same is not paid within 30 days after the date of the
notice, then such amount plus a 25% penalty charge shall be certified to the
County Auditor for collection the same as other taxes and assessments are
collected.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74; Am. Ord. 16-1979, passed 5-7-79; Am. Ord. 7-1984,
passed 4-16-84; Am. Ord. 29-1984, passed 9-4-84)
§ 94.15  UPSETTING PUBLIC OR PRIVATE RECEPTACLES.
   No person shall upset a public or private receptacle designed or used for
the deposit of litter or cause or permit its contents to be deposited or strewn
in or upon public or private property.
(Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89)
§ 94.16  LITTER THROWN BY PERSONS IN VEHICLE.
   No person, while driver or a passenger in a vehicle shall throw or deposit
litter upon any street or other public place within the city or upon private
property.
(Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89)
§ 94.17  TRUCK LOADS CAUSING LITTER.
   No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city
unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load,
contents, or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or
other public place.  Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck
within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any
street, alley, or other place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter, or foreign
matter of any kind.
(Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89)
§ 94.18  DUMPING.
   No person shall dump combustible waste material on any public or private
property other than on any authorized private landfill or disposal sites. 
Combustible waste material may be dumped on authorized private landfills or
disposal sites subject to criteria prescribed by the Director of Public Works. 
No person shall dump dirt or other noncombustible material of any kind on any
public or private property within the city without the written permission of
the owner or lessee thereof.
(Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89)
§ 94.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating the provisions of this §§
94.04,
94.05,
94.08 through
94.10,
94.12, or
94.17 shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof
shall be fined not more than $100.  Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder.
   (B)   Any person violating the provisions of §§
94.02,
94.03,
94.06,
94.07,
94.11,
94.13,
94.15, or
94.16 shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor for the first offense.  For
the second and subsequent violations, he or she shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree with a possible penalty of 60 days and/or $500
fine, in addition to or in lieu of the penalty provided in these sections,
could be ordered to remove litter from any public or private property or in or
on any waters of the city.  Each day such violation is committed or permitted
to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such
hereunder.
   (C)   Any person violating the provisions of §
94.18 shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor for the first offense.  For
the second and subsequent violations, he or she shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not
less than $250.  Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue
shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
   (D)   No refunds will be made if the amount claimed equals $5 or less. The
foregoing not withstanding, the City Manager is granted the discretionary
authority to order a refund, including but not limited to an amount of $5 or
less, where deemed to be reasonable and appropriate.
(Ord. 36-1974, passed 8-5-74; Am. Ord. 24-1989, passed 8-7-89; Am. Ord. 14-
1991, passed 5-20-91; Am. Ord. 03-2006, passed 3-6-06)

OHIO FIRE CODE
§ 95.01  ADOPTION OF THE OHIO FIRE CODE.
   The Ohio Fire Code as published by The International Code Council (ICC),
together with amendments herein provided in is hereby adopted as the Fire Code
of the City of Forest Park, Ohio.
(Ord. 02-2001, passed 6-4-01; Am. Ord. 07-2005, passed 4-4-05; Am. Ord. 16-
2007, passed 6-4-07; Am . Ord. 22-2012, passed 12-3-12; Am. Ord. 14-2015,
passed 8-3-15)
§ 95.02  AMENDMENTS TO THE OHIO FIRE CODE.
   The 2006 Edition of The International Fire Code is amended as follows:
   (A)   Section 105.8, add the following: “Permit fees shall be in accordance
with
Chapter 156 of the Forest Park Code of Ordinances, and shall be deposited in
and made part of the special fire fund”.
   (B)   Section C105.1 shall read: “the standard spacing for fire hydrants in
the Forest Park District shall be 350 feet between hydrants”.
   (C)   Section 507.2.1, add the following: “All underground valves
controlling fire protection system water supplies installed after April 1,
2011, shall be made accessible by installation in a concrete vault (valves pit)
equipped with a sump pump or gravity discharge. All buried valves installed
prior to April 1, 2011, and which are thereafter excavated for servicing or
repair are highly recommended to be reinstalled in a concrete vault (valve
pit)”.
(Ord. 02-2001, passed 6-4-01; Am. Ord. 07-2005, passed 4-4-05; Am. Ord. 16-
2007, passed 6-4-07; Am.  Ord. 22-2012. passed 12-3-12; Am. Ord. 14-2015,
passed 8-3-15)
PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS
§ 95.18  PERMIT AND ANNUAL INSPECTION REQUIRED FOR TYPE A AND B DAYCARE AND
GROUP HOMES.
   (A)   The Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer of the municipal corporation
in which a Type A home day care, Type B home day care or group home is located
shall annually conduct a fire safety inspection for compliance with the City of
Forest Park Fire Prevention Code. Upon completion and determining the Type A,
Type B or group home is in compliance, a permit shall be issued and remain in
effect for one year.
   (B)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      GROUP HOME. A facility housing any group of persons living together not
as family members in a single housekeeping unit. The group home will have a
staff member present.
      TYPE A HOME DAY CARE. A permanent residence of the administrator in which
child day-care is provided for seven to 12 children at one time.
      TYPE B HOME DAY CARE. A permanent residence of the administrator in which
child day-care is provided for one to six children at one time.
   (C)   Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a
minor misdemeanor for the first offense and be fined not more than $100. Unless
specifically stated elsewhere in this chapter, each and every day during which
a violation of this chapter occurs shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 14-2015, passed 8-3-15, Am. Ord. 04-2016, passed 3-21-16)
§ 95.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which another
penalty is not provided is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not
more than $100. Unless specifically stated elsewhere in this chapter, each and
every day during which a violation of this chapter continues shall be deemed a
separate offense.
   (B)   No refunds will be made if the amount claimed equals $5 or less. The
foregoing not withstanding, the City Manager is granted the discretionary
authority to order a refund, including but not limited to an amount of $5 or
less, where deemed to be reasonable and appropriate.
(Ord. 02-2016, passed 2-15-16)
